text:
Hi all
Can you pls help with the following.
Our IP is `167.99.58.34`

We are checking with the steps here <https://docs.dev.sync.global/validator_operator/validator_onboarding.html#validating-that-your-ip-has-been-approved>

and when we request
```for url in $(curl -sSL <https://scan.sv-1.dev.global.canton.network.sync.global/api/scan/v0/scans> | jq -r '.scans | .[].scans | .[] | .publicUrl' ); do  echo -n "$url: ";  curl -sSL --connect-timeout 5 --fail-with-body $url/api/scan/version | jq -r '.version'; done```
we get
```curl: (28) Failed to connect to scan.sv-1.dev.global.canton.network.sync.global port 443 after 300065 ms: Timeout was reached```

text:
That means you have not been whitelisted yet by that SV (and possibly the rest).

You can try replacing the url to any/all of the scan URLS listed at <https://sync.global/sv-network/> to check if any SV has whitelisted you

text:
You can rotate Canton-related keys from a Canton console. Sadly no newer docs yet but these should mostly still work: <https://docs.daml.com/canton/usermanual/security.html#rotating-canton-node-keys>

I would not recommend it unless you have a good reason... and then the answer is most likely "create a fresh node" instead.

I am mentioning though because we might mandate (automatic) key rotations for some Canton keys in the future. It's a tool we have to deal with bugs manifested in old topology transactions.

elements.text: You can rotate Canton-related keys from a Canton console. Sadly no newer docs yet but these should mostly still work:

I would not recommend it unless you have a good reason... and then the answer is most likely "create a fresh node" instead.

I am mentioning though because we might mandate (automatic) key rotations for some Canton keys in the future. It's a tool we have to deal with bugs manifested in old topology transactions.

text:
A user is reporting having issues with non AMD64 nodes on a kube deployment.
Is it correct that kube deployments should be using AMD64 only nodes?
If this is the case, I'll add to the doc.
for Docker, there is a mention that both AMD and ARM work, not sure for kube.

elements.text:
A user is reporting having issues with non AMD64 nodes on a kube deployment.
Is it correct that kube deployments should be using AMD64 only nodes?
If this is the case, I'll add to the doc.
for Docker, there is a mention that both AMD and ARM work, not sure for kube.

text:
yes, validator should work on amd64/arm64. I originallu used ARM to save cost, and validator works fine.

But the `utility` doesn't support arm64 yet so I migrated back to AMD.

elements.text:
yes, validator should work on amd64/arm64. I originallu used ARM to save cost, and validator works fine.

But the
utility
doesn't support arm64 yet so I migrated back to AMD.

text:
> (i'll try to find that message and ping you there)
Got distracted before I could update here: <@UUT0L5W2J> sent me the link, from what info was still there it looks like they bumped into a failure related to package vetting. Which means that importing the identity dump worked as it's an earlier init step.

The actual issue would likely have been solvable by one or more manual DAR uploads. We resolved at least one "DAR vetting deadlock around migrations" bug since this incident, so it's plausible that this particular issue is solved too now.

elements.text: (i'll try to find that message and ping you there)
Got distracted before I could update here:

sent me the link, from what info was still there it looks like they bumped into a failure related to package vetting. Which means that importing the identity dump worked as it's an earlier init step.

The actual issue would likely have been solvable by one or more manual DAR uploads. We resolved at least one "DAR vetting deadlock around migrations" bug since this incident, so it's plausible that this particular issue is solved too now.

text: Hey all, I cant see the answer here cause slack features deleted it - Im wondering the same, can someone confirm the only penalty would be the missed rewards the operator wouldnt receive while being down?

elements.text: Hey all, I cant see the answer here cause slack features deleted it - Im wondering the same, can someone confirm the only penalty would be the missed rewards the operator wouldnt receive while being down?

text:
No one but the Validator operator itself, and its customers, imposes any SLAs at the network level.

If you are part of a multi-party workflow, you might need to make SLA commitments to your counterparties that your node will stay up

And if you're an application provider you' may have SLAs with your customers

But the network itself doesn't much care if your Validator stays up; you just lose rewards, as you noted.

elements.text:
No one but the Validator operator itself, and its customers, imposes any SLAs at the network level.

If you are part of a multi-party workflow, you might need to make SLA commitments to your counterparties that your node will stay up

And if you're an application provider you' may have SLAs with your customers

But the network itself doesn't much care if your Validator stays up; you just lose rewards, as you noted.

elements.text: Makes sense, thank you!

text: The backup depends on the actual database type you deployed, i.e. Postgres or cloud SQL. For the specific DB you would follow the steps in the documentation, i.e. scale down the live nodes utilising the DBs, truncate and restore the DB from the backups (pg_restore) and then bring the nodes back online using the database.

elements.text: The backup depends on the actual database type you deployed, i.e. Postgres or cloud SQL. For the specific DB you would follow the steps in the documentation, i.e. scale down the live nodes utilising the DBs, truncate and restore the DB from the backups (pg_restore) and then bring the nodes back online using the database.

text: It is important the the further the data is from the seqeuncer, the earlier the backup so participant db then validator db, then any application dbs, etc. In this way the participant recovers from the synchronizers, the validator from the participant, etc. If you have the validator DB at or later than the participant then it will get confused as the participant may not have caught up and the validator may attempt to recover from an offset that the participant does not know about.

elements.text: It is important the the further the data is from the seqeuncer, the earlier the backup so participant db then validator db, then any application dbs, etc. In this way the participant recovers from the synchronizers, the validator from the participant, etc. If you have the validator DB at or later than the participant then it will get confused as the participant may not have caught up and the validator may attempt to recover from an offset that the participant does not know about.

I have tried to follow up on this <https://docs.sync.global/validator_operator/validator_disaster_recovery.html#kubernetes-deployment>, by destroying the environment and installing everything again using the node identity backup as secret and uncommenting
```# participantIdentitiesDumpImport:
#   secretName: participant-bootstrap-dump
#   # Make sure to also adjust nodeIdentifier to the same value
#   newParticipantIdentifier: put-some-new-string-never-used-before
# migrateValidatorParty: true```
